title: How to Insulate a Basement

steps.headline: Determine whether you are qualified to install basement insulation yourself.
steps.description: If not, contact a local contractor through the Insulation Contractors Association of America (ICAA) or ask friends and family that could recommend a trusted contractor.

steps.headline: Determine the R-value of the insulation to be installed.
steps.description: R-value represents the thermal resistance of the insulation. Guidelines and recommendations can be found through the International Energy Conservation Code. For the United States, most insulation falls somewhere between R-5 and R-10.

steps.headline: Purchase blanket insulation according to measurements.
Choose blanket insulation with or without facings.
steps.description: Facings are coverings over the insulation such as vinyl, foil, or craft paper.

steps.headline: Cut insulation to the measured specifications.
Staple insulation every 4 inches (10 cm) to the furring strips.
Tape seams of insulation and any tears or rips.

methods.name: Install concrete blocks infused with foam insulation.

steps.headline: These concrete blocks are usually installed at the time of construction or when the home is undergoing significant renovation.
steps.description: Unless you possess expert masonry skills, leave this kind of basement insulation to a cement mason.

steps.headline: Purchase concrete blocks infused with foam insulation.
steps.description: The two common forms sold are autoclaved aerated concrete (AAC) and autoclaved cellular concrete (ACC).

steps.headline: Most commonly, foam board is installed between an exterior finish such as siding and the exterior wall's studs.
Purchase foam board in one of its two forms: molded expandable polystyrene (MEPS) or extruded expandable polystyrene (XEPS).
Avoid exposure to direct sunlight, which can eventually damage the foam board.

methods.name: Install loose-fill insulation, which is intended for enclosed cavities or attics.

steps.headline: Purchase or rent special blowing equipment to distribute the insulation.
Drill two sets of holes.
steps.description: The top row should be 2 inches (5 cm) in diameter and 16 inches (41 cm) from the top of the wall. The bottom row should be vertically aligned with the top row and 24 inches (61 cm) from the bottom of the wall.

steps.headline: Work between the studs, and blow the insulation into the space through the holes.
Call a professional if you don't feel comfortable drilling, filling, or sealing the holes.

Steps Determine whether you are qualified to install basement insulation yourself. If not, contact a local contractor through the Insulation Contractors Association of America (ICAA) or ask friends and family that could recommend a trusted contractor. Determine the R-value of the insulation to be installed. R-value represents the thermal resistance of the insulation. Guidelines and recommendations can be found through the International Energy Conservation Code. For the United States, most insulation falls somewhere between R-5 and R-10. Measure intended space for insulation. Purchase blanket insulation according to measurements. This insulation is made of flexible fibers ranging from fiberglass to natural fibers such as sheep's wool. "} Choose blanket insulation with or without facings. Facings are coverings over the insulation such as vinyl, foil, or craft paper. Install furring strips. Cut insulation to the measured specifications. Staple insulation every 4 inches (10 cm) to the furring strips. Tape seams of insulation and any tears or rips. Install concrete blocks infused with foam insulation. These concrete blocks are usually installed at the time of construction or when the home is undergoing significant renovation. Unless you possess expert masonry skills, leave this kind of basement insulation to a cement mason. Purchase concrete blocks infused with foam insulation. The two common forms sold are autoclaved aerated concrete (AAC) and autoclaved cellular concrete (ACC). Install foam board. Most commonly, foam board is installed between an exterior finish such as siding and the exterior wall's studs. Purchase foam board in one of its two forms: molded expandable polystyrene (MEPS) or extruded expandable polystyrene (XEPS). Avoid exposure to direct sunlight, which can eventually damage the foam board. Install loose-fill insulation, which is intended for enclosed cavities or attics. Purchase or rent special blowing equipment to distribute the insulation. Drill two sets of holes. The top row should be 2 inches (5 cm) in diameter and 16 inches (41 cm) from the top of the wall. The bottom row should be vertically aligned with the top row and 24 inches (61 cm) from the bottom of the wall. Work between the studs, and blow the insulation into the space through the holes. Seal the drilled holes. Call a professional if you don't feel comfortable drilling, filling, or sealing the holes.
